docs.lead_paragraph: THREE hundred thousand pooches live in New York City. For dog walkers, that's a lot of plastic bags. But those who earn a living with a leash are not complaining. They are doing a land-office business. The prices, experience and services of these operations vary widely, and they range from part-time endeavors run from home by unemployed actors to companies with offices and full-time employees. But, though the field is diverse and largely unregulated, few people doubt that it is growing.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: You correctly note (front page, June 10) that most Medicare beneficiaries will be confused by the new health insurance options offered to them later this year. One vital fact that many of the elderly may not know is that they do not have to change their current Medicare coverage when the new plans become available. They can still remain in regular Medicare fee-for-service or with their Medicare health maintenance organization.

headline.main: Nation of Caregivers Needs Greater Foresight; Choice and Confusion

docs.lead_paragraph: This week, just days before the end of the 1998 legislative session, State Senator Nicholas A. Spano strolled through the lobby outside the Senate chamber, chatting quietly with a few colleagues and lobbyists. ''At this point in the session, usually I don't want to come out into the lobby for fear of getting attacked by people who want their pet bills,'' said Mr. Spano, a Republican from Yonkers who has been in the Legislature for 20 years. ''This is the quietest I've ever seen it at the end of session.''

headline.main: Legislative Session Ending Quietly, Stilled by Election-Year Inertia

docs.abstract: New York's 1998 legislative session ends quietly; combination of personal animosities among major players and election-year politics made for unusually quiet five-month session (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: As the baby-boomer generation ages, and in light of today's smaller families and the increase in the number of women working outside the home, American families' need for long-term care for elderly family members will increase exponentially, while the shortfall in caregiving becomes wider (news article, June 8).

headline.main: Nation of Caregivers Needs Greater Foresight

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your June 8 news article on long-term care for the elderly shows what is wrong with the Medicare system as it relates to home health and community-based long-term care. The Medicare system, established to cover the costs of acute illness for older people, was never meant to provide long-term home care.

headline.main: Nation of Caregivers Needs Greater Foresight; Bankrupting Ourselves

docs.lead_paragraph: Since the 1970's, the gap in wages between skilled and unskilled workers has widened sharply. But new research shows the inequality does not stop there. Discrepancies in job benefits and the quality of work life have also grown, pointing to a bigger chasm than previously recognized.

headline.main: BENEFITS DWINDLE ALONG WITH WAGES FOR THE UNSKILLED

docs.abstract: Gap in wages between skilled and unskilled workers has widened sharply since 1970's, but new research shows inequality does not stop there; discrepancies in job benefits and quality of work life have also grown, pointing to bigger chasm than previously recognized; study after study has shown that gains from post-1970's economic growth have eluded unskilled workers; while specialists have long assumed that benefits acted as leveling influence, particularly because of Government-required benefits like Social Security and unemployment insurance, opposite is true; Labor Dept economist Brooks Pierce comments; graphs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Medicare recipients will soon have a wide range of health insurance options like those available to workers in private industry. Consumer advocates predict that the new choices will be confusing to the elderly, most of whom have little experience with managed health care.

docs.lead_paragraph: What's in a name? Increasingly for makers of generic drugs, everything -- a seemingly odd state of affairs for an industry whose stock in trade is cheap no-name knockoffs of brands that have lost their patents. With too many players in too many parts of the business, companies that primarily sell generics often find themselves lost in the crowd, able to stand out on pharmacy shelves only by cutting prices. More and more, though, they are replacing the identically drab scientific labels on their products with brand names of their own, raising prices in step with a higher profile.

headline.main: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Old Drugs, New Labels; Brand Name Generics and Other Linguistic Anomalies

docs.abstract: Some makers of generic drugs are adopting new business strategies, including devloping brands of their own, to differentiate themselves in sea of cheap knockoffs of brand name drugs; focuses on strategies of Watson Pharmaceuticals, Alpharma Inc and Teva Pharmaceutical Industries; photo of Watson chief executive Allen Chao; chart (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: I once wrote an article about a young drug dealer in New Haven. Afterward, he and I kept in touch. In the mid-1990's, when a police crackdown temporarily suppressed the New Haven drug trade, he told me, ''People are scared now, so they're just getting, like, jobs.'' His tone was pitying, appalled. Jobs were apparently only for the truly desperate. This scandalous idea comes back to me whenever I hear that unemployment is low. It's the street version of what all economists know: that a huge number of jobs these days do not pay a living wage. John E. Schwarz, in a comprehensive calculation of opportunity versus need published last year, found there were 16 million more households in the United States than there were adequately paying jobs, a shortfall that has been growing since the 1970's and that, according to Mr. Schwarz, is unlikely to ease.

headline.main: Prosperous Times, Except for the Young

docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by author William Finnegan says future holds few economic rewards for nation's youth, who are being shunted to ranks of working poor as nation's middle class shrinks; says their economic prospects have been deteriorating for generation; collage (M)
